panels.description:
This shows the role of the selected instance. Normally this should be one of ``PRIMARY``, ``SECONDARY`` and ``ARBITER``, but if the system is newly added it could show ``STARTUP2`` during its initial sync.

Read more about [Replica Set Member States](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/replica-states/).
panels.title: ReplSet State

panels.description: This shows how many members are configured in the replica set.
panels.title: ReplSet Members

panels.description: This shows the time since the last election.
panels.title: ReplSet Last Election

panels.description: This panel shows how far behind in replication this member is if it is a secondary. This number may be high it the instance is running as a delayed secondary member.

targets.expr: avg by (service_name) ((max(mongodb_mongod_replset_member_optime_date{state="PRIMARY", set="$replset"})) - avg by (service_name) (min(mongodb_mongod_replset_member_optime_date{state="SECONDARY"}) * on (name) group_left avg by (service_name) (mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name{service_name=~"$service_name"}))) or vector(0)

panels.title: ReplSet Lag

panels.description: This shows which storage engine the instance is configured with.
panels.title: Storage Engine

panels.description: Replicated Ops/sec on secondaries. Classified by legacy wire protocol type (insert, update, and delete only)
panels.title: Replication Operations

panels.description: Timespan 'window' between newest and the oldest op in the Oplog collection
panels.title: Oplog Recovery Window

targets.expr: avg by (service_name) ((max(mongodb_mongod_replset_member_optime_date{state="PRIMARY", set="$replset"})) - avg by (service_name) (min(mongodb_mongod_replset_member_optime_date{state="SECONDARY"}) * on (name) group_left avg by (service_name) (mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name{service_name=~"$service_name"}))) or vector(0)

panels.description: Count of elections. Usually zero; 1 count by each healthy node will appear in each election. Happens when the primary role changes due to either normal maintenance or trouble events.
panels.title: Elections

panels.description: mongod uptime + replication state, as reported via replSetGetStatus

targets.expr:
avg by (service_name,state,name) (mongodb_mongod_replset_member_uptime{service_name=~"$service_name"})
* on (name) group_right(state) (avg by (service_name,state,name) (max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name[$interval]) or max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name[5m])))

panels.title: Member State Uptime

panels.description: Time span between now and last heartbeat from replicaset members.

targets.expr: time() - avg by (service_name) (max(mongodb_mongod_replset_member_last_heartbeat{service_name=~"$service_name"}) by (name)) * on (name) group_right avg by (service_name) (mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name{service_name=~"$service_name"})

panels.title: Max Heartbeat Time

targets.expr:
avg by (service_name,name,state) (mongodb_mongod_replset_member_ping_ms{service_name=~"$service_name"})
* on (name) group_right(state) avg by (service_name,state,name) ((max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name[$interval]) or max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_replset_my_name[5m])))

panels.description: Time spent per second waiting for or fetching oplog docs in replication.
panels.title: Oplog Getmore Time

panels.description: Count of A) getmores executed B) index values pre-loaded C) oplog docs applied per second against oplog collection in replication.
panels.title: Oplog Operations

panels.description: Times spent per second A) pre-loading oplog ops into parallel-executable batches B) MMAP only) Times spent pre-loading index values and C) repl batch apply phase
panels.title: Oplog Processing Time

panels.description: Repl buffer ops applied per sec.
panels.title: Oplog Buffered Operations

panels.description: Current hard-coded max and actual size of repl batch buffer
panels.title: Oplog Buffer Capacity

panels.description:
This shows the number of active connections on the server. Keep in mind the hard limit on the maximum number of connections set by your distribution.

You can read more about the [connection numbers](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/administration/analyzing-mongodb-performance/#number-of-connections).

targets.expr:
avg by (service_name) (max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_connections{service_name=~"$service_name", state="current"}[$interval]) or 
max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_connections{service_name=~"$service_name", state="current"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongos_connections{service_name=~"$service_name", state="current"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongos_connections{service_name=~"$service_name", state="current"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_connections{service_name=~"$service_name", state="current"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_connections{service_name=~"$service_name", state="current"}[5m]))

panels.title: Connections

panels.description: This shows the number of open cursors for each shard in the cluster. A cursor in MongoDB is a pointer to the result of a given query that can be iterated over. By default a cursor times out after 10 minutes.

targets.expr:
avg by (service_name,state) (max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_metrics_cursor_open{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_metrics_cursor_open{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_cursors{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongod_cursors{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongos_metrics_cursor_open{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or 
max_over_time(mongodb_mongos_metrics_cursor_open{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongos_cursors{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mongodb_mongos_cursors{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]))

panels.title: Cursors

panels.description: The parameter shows how long a system has been “up” and running without a shut down or restart.
panels.title: System Uptime

panels.description: The system load is a measurement of the computational work the system is performing. Each running process either using or waiting for CPU resources adds 1 to the load.
panels.title: Load Average

panels.description: RAM (Random Access Memory) is the hardware in a computing device where the operating system, application programs and data in current use are kept so they can be quickly reached by the device's processor.
panels.title: RAM

panels.description:
Percent of Memory Available
Note: on Modern Linux Kernels amount of Memory Available for application is not the same as Free+Cached+Buffers
panels.title: Memory Available

panels.description: RAM + SWAP
panels.title: Virtual Memory

panels.description: Sum of disk space on all partitions. Note  it can be significantly over-reported in some installations
panels.title: Disk Space

panels.description: Lowest percent of the disk space available
panels.title: Min Space Available

panels.description: The CPU time is measured in clock ticks or seconds. It is useful to measure CPU time as a percentage of the CPU's capacity, which is called the CPU usage.

targets.expr: clamp_max(((avg by (mode) ( (clamp_max(rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name",mode!="idle"}[$interval]),1)) or (clamp_max(irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name",mode!="idle"}[5m]),1)) ))*100 or (avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$node_name", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$node_name", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[5m]))),100)

panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: When a system is running with maximum CPU utilization, the transmitting and receiving threads must all share the available CPU. This will cause data to be queued more frequently to cope with the lack of CPU. CPU Saturation may be measured as the length of a wait queue, or the time spent waiting on the queue.
panels.title: CPU Saturation and Max Core Usage

panels.description:
Disk I/O includes read or write or input/output operations involving a physical disk. It is the speed with which the data transfer takes place between the hard disk drive and RAM.

Swap Activity is memory management that involves swapping sections of memory to and from physical storage.
panels.title: Disk I/O and Swap Activity

panels.description: Network traffic refers to the amount of data moving across a network at a given point in time.

targets.expr: avg by (node_name) (sum(rate(node_network_receive_bytes_total{node_name="$node_name", device!="lo"}[$interval])) or sum(irate(node_network_receive_bytes_total{node_name="$node_name", device!="lo"}[5m])) or sum(max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_network_rx{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval])) or sum(max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_network_rx{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])))

avg by (node_name) (sum(rate(node_network_transmit_bytes_total{node_name="$node_name", device!="lo"}[$interval])) or sum(irate(node_network_transmit_bytes_total{node_name="$node_name", device!="lo"}[5m])) or
sum(max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_network_tx{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval])) or sum(max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_network_tx{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])))

panels.title: Network Traffic
